awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Phonetics of period doubling
awd_abstract_narration:
The human voice is an essential part of speech, serving to identify and distinguish talkers. A fundamental question regarding human language is how voice quality affects speech production and perception. This project approaches the question by looking at “period doubling” in natural speech, where a voice has a rough quality and more than one pitch. This also frequently occurs in pathological voice and singing styles. This dissertation project provides insight into 1) the articulatory and acoustic properties of period doubling, compared to those of other voice qualities; 2) the interaction between perceived pitch and voice quality in period doubling; and 3) the role of period doubling in the perception of linguistic tone. The findings are relevant to theories of the voice in linguistics, speech-language pathology, and music. The study of voice quality improves our understanding of the differences between typical and disordered voices, which can be used by clinicians to improve diagnoses and therapy strategies for individuals with vocal pathology. A better understanding of the distribution of period doubling in typical speech is also important to improving pitch detection and voice synthesis technologies, which are used in text-to-speech and automatic speech recognition.

The current project serves as a probe of how people produce and make use of voice quality when processing linguistic information. It consists of three studies. Study 1 includes a production experiment of different voice types in a tonal language to investigate the articulatory and acoustic properties of period doubling and its linguistic distribution. Study 2 investigates pitch and voice perception during period doubling using synthesized speech that is controlled for various acoustic properties. Study 3 investigates the role of period doubling and other voice qualities in tone identification, with the goal of explaining the interaction between pitch and voice in different voice types, and the roles they play in distinguishing words.

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated the role of voice quality in tone production and perception, with a focus on an under-studied yet commonly-occurring subtype of creaky voice: period doubling. This voice quality contains multiple fundamental frequencies and often leads to an indeterminate pitch. Investigating the characteristics of period doubling is crucial for our understanding of the interaction between pitch and voice in linguistic contrasts.

The outcomes of this dissertation project provided direct answers to the following questions: 1) What are the articulatory and acoustic properties of period doubling? 2) Where does period doubling occur and how it is conditioned by tone and phrasing?  3) What is the role of period doubling in pitch and lexical tone perception? Mandarin Chinese was chosen as the target language because period doubling and other voice qualities such as vocal fry are common in Mandarin tone production. See the image for an example of period doubling and vocal fry in electroglottography (EGG) and audio waveforms.

Our findings suggest that period doubling involves simultaneous articulation of two distinct voice qualities as well as pitches. We also found that period doubling is more likely to occur at utterance edges, likely due to vocal instability in those environments. We also tested how Mandarin and English speakers perceive and imitate novel linguistic tones manipulated with period doubling. In general, we found that period doubling tended to be perceived and imitated as a low and irregular tone. We did not find any effect of language or musical experience, suggesting that the perception of period doubling is not language- specific or conditioned by non-linguistic tonal knowledge.

Beyond its relevance for linguistics, this research is also relevant for broader voice studies. The articulatory and perceptual qualities of period doubling are of practical interest to speech and voice clinicians, as well as to singing instructors, because period doubling is found in vocal pathology (“diplophonia”) and singing styles (e.g., Sardinian singing). This work contributes to our understanding of the differences between typical and disordered voices, which in turn can be used by clinicians to improve diagnoses and therapy strategies of vocal pathology. In addition, this dissertation can contribute to improved pitch detection, irregular voice detection, and better synthesis of voice quality. The findings are also useful in techniques such as text-to-speech and automatic speech recognition.
